newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan consortium wins China financial system order.
newsitem.headline: Japan consortium wins China financial system order.

text.p: A Japanese consortium, including Hitachi Ltd, Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp (NTT) and NTT Data Communications System Corp, said on Thursday it had won an order for a financial settlement system from the People's Bank of China.
The consortium also includes Itochu Corp and Marubeni Corp, the companies said in a statement.
The statement did not say what the order was worth.
The system, called "China National Automated Payment System," would become the core of financial modernisation in China, the statement said.
The Chinese Academy of Science will also take part in the project, it said.
The agreement was signed between NTT Data and the People's Bank of China together with the China National Instruments Import and Export Corp, the statement said.
It said NTT Data would be responsible for system integration and would develop application software, in addition to overseeing the project as a whole.
The statement said the Chinese Academy of Science would cooperate with NTT Data in developing application software, while NTT would be in charge of the communications network system.
Hitachi and International Business Machines Corp (IBM) would have responsibility for computer systems and Marubeni and Itochu would be in charge of commercial affairs and trading duties, it said.
The new system would use both satellite and ground networks to link 100 branches of the People's Bank of China and 500 branches of five commercial banks, the statement said.

The People's Bank of China has outlined a rough schedule to start in the first half of 1997 to build a pilot system for the network. The pilot system is expected to be completed within two and a half years, the statement said.
It said the system would initially be used in 100 cities and was eventually expected to be used nationwide.
The People's Bank of China has branches in more than 2,000 cities throughout China.
